weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-89: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an SQL Command ('SQL Injection') The product constructs all or part of an SQL command using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended SQL command when it is sent to a downstream component.

countermeasure.name: Configure origin access control to restrict CloudFront distribution access
countermeasure.desc: To enhance the security of your AWS CloudFront distributions, implement Origin Access Control (OAC) to restrict access to your origin servers. By configuring OAC, you ensure that only CloudFront has the necessary permissions to fetch content from the origin, preventing unauthorized access and modifications. This control involves creating an OAC, attaching it to your CloudFront distribution, and configuring your origin server (e.g., S3 bucket, custom origin) to only accept requests signed with the OAC signature. Regularly review and update OAC settings to align with any changes in your security posture or application architecture. Refer to AWS CloudFront Security Best Practices for detailed configuration steps and requirements.

reference.name: Restrict access to an AWS origin

countermeasure.name: Enforce HTTPS for all data transmission and redirect HTTP to HTTPS
countermeasure.desc: To secure data transmitted between CloudFront and both viewers and origin servers, ensure that all communication is encrypted using HTTPS. Configure your CloudFront distribution to automatically redirect all incoming HTTP requests to HTTPS, preventing unencrypted data transmission. This can be achieved by setting up a custom error response for HTTP requests or by enforcing HTTPS in the CloudFront behavior settings. By enforcing HTTPS and redirecting HTTP traffic, you protect sensitive information from being intercepted, ensuring secure communication across your entire CloudFront distribution.

reference.name: Require HTTPS for communication between viewers and CloudFront

countermeasure.name: Implement signed URLs and signed cookies to restrict content access
countermeasure.desc: To ensure that only authorized users can access specific resources served by your AWS CloudFront distribution, use signed URLs and signed cookies. Signed URLs are ideal for granting temporary access to individual files, while signed cookies allow access to multiple restricted files. Configure these mechanisms to include expiration dates and IP whitelisting to further control access. Generate and manage the cryptographic keys securely to prevent unauthorized use. By implementing signed URLs and signed cookies, you can effectively restrict content access, protecting your resources from unauthorized distribution or consumption.

reference.name: Serve private content with signed URLs and signed cookies

countermeasure.name: Integrate AWS WAF with CloudFront to mitigate web exploits
countermeasure.desc: To protect your AWS CloudFront distribution from common web exploits such as SQL injection and cross-site scripting (XSS), integrate AWS Web Application Firewall (WAF) with CloudFront. AWS WAF allows you to create custom rules that filter and monitor HTTP and HTTPS requests based on defined conditions. Implement predefined managed rule groups for comprehensive protection against known vulnerabilities, and configure custom rules tailored to your applications specific security requirements. Regularly review and update your WAF rules to adapt to evolving threats, ensuring that your CloudFront distribution remains secure against web-based attacks.

countermeasure.name: Utilize version control for CloudFront configuration management
countermeasure.desc: Implement version control to manage and track changes to your AWS CloudFront distribution configurations. This practice allows you to maintain a history of configuration changes, making it easier to identify, audit, and revert any unintended or harmful modifications. Use tools such as AWS CloudFormation, Terraform, or Git to version your configuration files, enabling consistent and repeatable deployments. In case of a misconfiguration or security issue, version control provides a straightforward path to roll back to a previous stable state, ensuring the reliability and security of your CloudFront distribution.

reference.name: Use file versioning to update or remove content with a CloudFront distribution

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data leakage through unencrypted data in transit
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Data leakage occurs when sensitive information is transmitted over the network without encryption. In AWS CloudFront, this happens when data moves between edge locations, clients, or origin servers using insecure protocols like HTTP, making it vulnerable to interception.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, state-sponsored actors, competitors.
  • Attack Vectors: Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) attacks, packet sniffing, compromised network infrastructure.

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Exposure of sensitive data like login credentials and personal information.
  • Integrity: Potential alteration of data in transit.
  • Reputation: Damage to brand trust and legal repercussions.
  • Financial Loss: Regulatory fines, litigation costs, and loss of business.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Scenario 1: An attacker intercepts unencrypted HTTP traffic on public Wi-Fi to steal user credentials.
  2. Scenario 2: Unencrypted software updates are intercepted and maliciously altered.
  3. Scenario 3: A state-sponsored actor intercepts unencrypted corporate data, leading to espionage.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1032 - Standard Cryptographic Protocol

threat.name: Unauthorized access to CloudFront distribution
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Unauthorized access to a CloudFront distribution occurs when an attacker gains access to the CloudFront distribution settings or content without proper authorization. This can lead to the manipulation of distribution settings, theft of sensitive data, or disruption of services.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, unauthorized users.
  • Attack Vectors: Compromised AWS credentials, insufficient access controls, exposed API keys.

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Unauthorized users may access or steal sensitive content.
  • Integrity: Attackers could modify distribution settings or content, leading to the distribution of malicious or incorrect information.
  • Availability: Attackers may disrupt services by altering or disabling the distribution.
  • Reputation: Loss of customer trust and potential legal consequences from data breaches.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Scenario 1: An attacker uses compromised AWS credentials to access and alter CloudFront settings, redirecting users to malicious content.
  2. Scenario 2: Insufficient access controls allow a former employee to log in and disrupt the CloudFront distribution, causing service outages.
  3. Scenario 3: An exposed API key is exploited to access CloudFront configurations, resulting in unauthorized changes to content delivery.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Misconfigured CloudFront distributions
threat.desc:
General Threat Description Misconfigured CloudFront distributions can lead to serious security vulnerabilities, such as unauthorized access, data exposure, or service disruptions. These misconfigurations may include improper access settings, insecure SSL/TLS configurations, or incorrect origin server permissions, making the distribution susceptible to attacks.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, careless administrators.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploitation of public S3 buckets, unauthorized access to CloudFront distributions, insecure SSL/TLS settings.

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Exposure of sensitive data to unauthorized users.
  • Integrity: Potential modification of data served by CloudFront.
  • Availability: Disruptions in service or unintended public access to private content.
  • Reputation: Damage to brand image due to security incidents.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Scenario 1: An S3 bucket linked to CloudFront is left publicly accessible, allowing attackers to download sensitive files.
  2. Scenario 2: A misconfigured SSL/TLS setting allows attackers to perform a MitM attack, intercepting data between the client and CloudFront.
  3. Scenario 3: Origin server permissions are too broad, allowing unauthorized users to alter content served by CloudFront.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1578.005 - Modify Cloud Compute Configurations

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Content tampering
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Content tampering occurs when an attacker alters the content delivered through a CloudFront distribution. This can involve modifying or injecting malicious code, defacing web pages, or changing the data served to end-users. Such tampering can lead to a variety of harmful outcomes, including the distribution of malware, misinformation, or unauthorized data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Cybercriminals, hacktivists, malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploitation of vulnerabilities in origin servers, unauthorized access to CloudFront configurations, man-in-the-middle (MitM) attacks.

Impacts

  • Integrity: Altered content can mislead users, distribute malware, or damage trust.
  • Reputation: Users may lose trust in the organization due to the distribution of tampered or harmful content.
  • Legal and Compliance: Organizations may face legal action or fines if tampered content results in harm to users or violates regulations.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Scenario 1: An attacker gains unauthorized access to the origin server and modifies the web application files, causing users to download malware.
  2. Scenario 2: A hacker intercepts and alters data being transmitted from the origin to CloudFront, leading to the delivery of defaced or misleading content.
  3. Scenario 3: A malicious insider modifies content on an origin server that is distributed via CloudFront, resulting in the display of unauthorized or offensive material.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1492 - Stored Data Manipulation

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

countermeasure.name: Implement multi-zone deployment for enhanced application resilience
countermeasure.desc: To maximize the high availability and fault tolerance of your applications monitored by AWS CloudWatch, deploy application resources across multiple Availability Zones within your AWS environment. This strategy involves setting up application instances in different geographical locations to ensure that in the event of a zone failure, at least one instance remains operational, thus maintaining service continuity. Use AWS services like Elastic Load Balancing (ELB) to distribute incoming traffic across these zones dynamically. Regularly test the failover process to verify that automatic switching between zones occurs seamlessly during an outage. Ensure that your CloudWatch alarms and metrics are configured to track the health and performance across all zones to facilitate prompt detection and response to potential issues.

standard.ref: Notice at Collection of Personal Information (e)(4)

countermeasure.name: Implement VPC and AWS PrivateLink for secure network isolation
countermeasure.desc: Enhance the security of your AWS CloudWatch implementation by utilizing Virtual Private Clouds (VPCs) and AWS PrivateLink to achieve network isolation and secure connectivity. Configure your CloudWatch resources within a VPC to control the network traffic that can reach your resources based on strict routing and security rules. This setup prevents unwanted traffic from accessing your monitoring environment. Additionally, integrate AWS PrivateLink to securely connect your VPC to CloudWatch without exposing your traffic to the public internet. This ensures that all data traffic between your VPC and CloudWatch transits over the AWS network, enhancing security and reducing exposure to external threats. Regularly audit your VPC and PrivateLink configurations to ensure they align with evolving security best practices and organizational needs.

reference.name: Using CloudWatch and CloudWatch Synthetics with interface VPC endpoints

countermeasure.name: Integrate Amazon Macie for enhanced data protection in S3
countermeasure.desc: To ensure the security of sensitive data stored in Amazon S3, integrate Amazon Macie, a security service that uses machine learning and pattern matching to automatically discover, classify, and protect sensitive data. Start by enabling Macie from the AWS Management Console and configuring it to monitor your S3 buckets. Define classification jobs in Macie to continuously assess the data being stored, identifying and classifying sensitive data such as personally identifiable information (PII), financial information, or health records. Utilize Macie's automated alerts to receive notifications of suspicious data access or potential data leaks. Regularly review Macie findings and audit reports to refine your data protection strategies, ensure compliance with privacy regulations, and enhance your overall security posture. Implement policies based on Macie recommendations to further restrict access to sensitive files and apply additional encryption settings as necessary.

reference.name: Using Amazon Macie to Validate S3 Bucket Data Classification

countermeasure.name: Secure data transmission and storage with enhanced logging
countermeasure.desc: Ensure the confidentiality and integrity of your AWS CloudWatch data with comprehensive security measures for both data in transit and at rest. Implement SSL/TLS protocols to secure all data transmissions to and from AWS services. For data at rest, enable encryption using AWS-managed keys or bring your own keys (BYOK) through AWS Key Management Service (KMS) to encrypt your CloudWatch logs and other sensitive data stored across AWS services. Additionally, leverage AWS CloudTrail to log and monitor all API calls to the AWS CloudWatch service, including accesses and changes made to your configurations and resources. This provides an auditable trail that can help detect unauthorized access or anomalies in usage patterns, thereby enhancing your security posture. Regularly review and update your encryption and logging practices to adapt to new security threats and compliance requirements.

reference.name: Data protection in Amazon CloudWatch Logs

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Lack of resilience
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Lack of resilience in AWS CloudWatch pertains to the inadequacies in ensuring that monitoring and alert systems remain functional during partial or complete service disruptions. This issue can stem from insufficient failover setups, lack of redundancy across geographical regions, or suboptimal configuration of resilience features provided by AWS.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

The primary agents are system failures, natural disasters, and network disruptions that can lead to the unavailability of CloudWatch in certain regions. These are often compounded by inadequate disaster recovery planning and the absence of automated failover mechanisms which should ideally support continuous monitoring across multiple regions.

Impacts

The consequences of resilience failures in CloudWatch include missed alerts, data loss, and gaps in monitoring, which can severely impact operational decision-making and response times during critical incidents. This can result in extended downtimes and, subsequently, financial losses and damage to customer trust.

Example Attack Scenarios

In one scenario, an organization relies solely on CloudWatch in a single AWS region for all its application monitoring. During a regional AWS outage, CloudWatch fails to continue monitoring, as there is no configuration in place to failover to another region. As a result, significant performance issues affecting customer transactions go unnoticed, leading to operational disruptions and a loss of revenue until the original region is restored.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Inadequate data protection
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Inadequate data protection in AWS CloudWatch refers to insufficient safeguards that fail to secure data against unauthorized access, alteration, or destruction. This vulnerability can stem from non-implementation of encryption, inadequate access controls, or the lack of robust data integrity checks, exposing sensitive monitoring data to potential threats.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include both external attackers and internal users who may exploit weak data protection measures to access or manipulate CloudWatch data. Common attack vectors involve intercepting data in transit, accessing unencrypted data at rest, or exploiting insufficiently protected API endpoints.

Impacts

The primary impacts of inadequate data protection in CloudWatch are unauthorized access to sensitive data, data manipulation, and potential data loss. These issues can lead to compliance violations, financial losses due to fines or remediation costs, and damage to the organization's reputation.

Example Attack Scenarios

Scenario 1: An organization fails to enable encryption for data stored in CloudWatch logs. An external attacker gains access to these logs through a compromised IAM role, retrieving sensitive information that was captured by the logging service.

Outcome: The exposure of sensitive information leads to a data breach, requiring notification to affected parties and resulting in significant reputational and financial damage.

Scenario 2: Due to inadequate network security controls, an attacker is able to perform a man-in-the-middle attack on data being transmitted from EC2 instances to CloudWatch. This allows the attacker to intercept and manipulate performance data.

Outcome: The tampered data misleads the organization's operational decisions, causing poor resource allocation and system performance issues, leading to operational inefficiencies and increased costs.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Vulnerabilities in infrastructure security
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Vulnerabilities in infrastructure security within AWS CloudWatch relate to weaknesses or gaps in the underlying physical and virtual infrastructure that supports CloudWatch. This includes but is not limited to network configurations, server security, and the integration of CloudWatch with other AWS services. These vulnerabilities can be exploited to disrupt service, gain unauthorized access, or manipulate data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

The threat agents can range from external hackers to internal employees with malicious intent. Attack vectors include exploiting outdated systems, misconfigured networks, or weaknesses in the security protocols that protect the data transmission and storage within CloudWatch.

Impacts

The consequences of these vulnerabilities can be severe, including data breaches, unauthorized access to sensitive monitoring data, and manipulation of configuration settings. These issues can lead to broader security incidents, affecting the integrity and availability of applications and services monitored by CloudWatch. Additionally, they can result in compliance failures and significant reputational damage.

Example Attack Scenarios

Scenario 1: An attacker exploits an unpatched vulnerability in the network infrastructure that supports AWS CloudWatch, allowing them to intercept and manipulate monitoring data being transmitted between AWS services.

Outcome: The manipulated data leads to incorrect automated scaling decisions, causing system instability and performance degradation, which impacts the organization's operational efficiency and service delivery.

Scenario 2: Due to improperly configured network access controls within the virtual private cloud (VPC) used by CloudWatch, an unauthorized user gains access to the CloudWatch management console.

Outcome: The unauthorized access allows the attacker to alter monitoring thresholds and disable alerts, resulting in delayed detection of a critical infrastructure failure. This oversight leads to extended downtime and considerable financial loss due to disrupted operations.

weakness.name: CWE-1115
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1115: Source Code Element without Standard Prologue The source code contains elements such as source files that do not consistently provide a prologue or header that has been standardized for the project.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-664
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-664: Improper Control of a Resource Through its Lifetime The product does not maintain or incorrectly maintains control over a resource throughout its lifetime of creation, use, and release.

weakness.name: CWE-732
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-732: Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource The product specifies permissions for a security-critical resource in a way that allows that resource to be read or modified by unintended actors. When a resource is given a permission setting that provides access to a wider range of actors than required, it could lead to the exposure of sensitive information, or the modification of that resource by unintended parties. This is especially dangerous when the resource is related to program configuration, execution, or sensitive user data. For example, consider a misconfigured storage account for the cloud that can be read or written by a public or anonymous user.

weakness.name: CWE-923
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-923: Improper Restriction of Communication Channel to Intended Endpoints The product establishes a communication channel to (or from) an endpoint for privileged or protected operations, but it does not properly ensure that it is communicating with the correct endpoint.

countermeasure.name: Lambda function policies should prohibit public access
countermeasure.desc:
This control checks whether the Lambda function resource-based policy prohibits public access outside of your account. The control fails if public access is permitted. The control also fails if a Lambda function is invoked from Amazon S3, and the policy doesn't include a condition to limit public access, such as AWS:SourceAccount. We recommend using other S3 conditions along with AWS:SourceAccount in your bucket policy for more refined access.

The Lambda function should not be publicly accessible, as this may allow unintended access to your function code.

Remediation

To remediate this issue, you must update your function's resource-based policy to remove permissions or to add the AWS:SourceAccount condition. You can only update the resource-based policy from the Lambda API or AWS CLI.

To start, review the resource-based policy on the Lambda console. Identify the policy statement that has Principal field values that make the policy public, such as "*" or { "AWS": "*" }.

You cannot edit the policy from the console. To remove permissions from the function, run the remove-permission command from the AWS CLI.

 

$ aws lambda remove-permission --function-name <function-name> --statement-id <statement-id>

Replace <function-name> with the name of the Lambda function, and <statement-id> with the statement ID (Sid) of the statement that you want to remove.

countermeasure.name: Lambda functions should be in a VPC
countermeasure.desc:
This control checks whether a Lambda function is deployed in a virtual private cloud (VPC). The control fails if the Lambda function isn't deployed in a VPC. Security Hub doesn't evaluate the VPC subnet routing configuration to determine public reachability. You might see failed findings for Lambda@Edge resources.

Deploying resources in a VPC strengthens security and control over network configurations. Such deployments also offer scalability and high fault tolerance across multiple Availability Zones. You can customize VPC deployments to meet diverse application requirements.

Remediation

To configure an existing function to connect to private subnets in your VPC, see Configuring VPC access in the AWS Lambda Developer Guide. We recommend choosing at least two private subnets for high availability and at least one security group that meets the connectivity requirements of the function.

countermeasure.name: Lambda functions should be tagged
countermeasure.desc:
This control checks whether an AWS Lambda function has tags with the specific keys defined in the parameter requiredTagKeys. The control fails if the function doesnt have any tag keys or if it doesnt have all the keys specified in the parameter requiredTagKeys. If the parameter requiredTagKeys isn't provided, the control only checks for the existence of a tag key and fails if the function isn't tagged with any key. System tags, which are automatically applied and begin with aws:, are ignored.

A tag is a label that you assign to an AWS resource, and it consists of a key and an optional value. You can create tags to categorize resources by purpose, owner, environment, or other criteria. Tags can help you identify, organize, search for, and filter resources. Tagging also helps you track accountable resource owners for actions and notifications. When you use tagging, you can implement attribute-based access control (ABAC) as an authorization strategy, which defines permissions based on tags. You can attach tags to IAM entities (users or roles) and to AWS resources. You can create a single ABAC policy or a separate set of policies for your IAM principals. You can design these ABAC policies to allow operations when the principal's tag matches the resource tag. For more information, see What is ABAC for AWS? in the IAM User Guide.

countermeasure.name: Lambda functions should use supported runtimes
countermeasure.desc:
This control checks whether AWS Lambda function runtime settings match the expected values set for the supported runtimes in each language. The control fails if the Lambda function doesn't use a supported runtime, noted previously under parameters. Security Hub ignores functions that have a package type of Image.

Lambda runtimes are built around a combination of operating system, programming language, and software libraries that are subject to maintenance and security updates. When a runtime component is no longer supported for security updates, Lambda deprecates the runtime. Even though you can't create functions that use the deprecated runtime, the function is still available to process invocation events. We recommend ensuring that your Lambda functions are current and don't use deprecated runtime environments. For a list of supported runtimes, see Lambda runtimes in the AWS Lambda Developer Guide.

Remediation

For more information about supported runtimes and deprecation schedules, see Runtime deprecation policy in the AWS Lambda Developer Guide. When you migrate your runtimes to the latest version, follow the syntax and guidance from the publishers of the language. We also recommend applying runtime updates to help reduce the risk of impact to your workloads in the rare event of a runtime version incompatibility.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1034 - Limit Hardware Installation

countermeasure.name: VPC Lambda functions should operate in multiple Availability Zones
countermeasure.desc:
This control checks if an AWS Lambda function that connects to a virtual private cloud (VPC) operates in at least the specified number of Availability Zone (AZs). The control fails if the function doesn't operate in at least the specified number of AZs. Unless you provide a custom parameter value for the minimum number of AZs, Security Hub uses a default value of two AZs.

Deploying resources across multiple AZs is an AWS best practice to ensure high availability within your architecture. Availability is a core pillar in the confidentiality, integrity, and availability triad security model. All Lambda functions that connect to a VPC should have a multi-AZ deployment to ensure that a single zone of failure doesn't cause a total disruption of operations.

Remediation

If you configure your function to connect to a VPC in your account, specify subnets in multiple AZs to ensure high availability. For instructions, see Configuring VPC access in the AWS Lambda Developer Guide.

Lambda automatically runs other functions in multiple AZs to ensure that it is available to process events in case of a service interruption in a single zone.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Serverless function misconfiguration
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

A serverless function misconfiguration refers to a software security risk that arises when serverless functions are configured inaccurately during their set-up or use. Serverless functions represent a new wave of cloud computing and offer a range of benefits, including scalability and reduced operational costs. However, the potentially complex configurations they entail can lead to vulnerabilities if not properly handled. This threat can leave applications open to data breaches, unauthorized access, and various kinds of cyber-attacks. 

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

These threats usually result from human error rather than being initiated by a specific threat agent. Common problems include inappropriate permission settings, insecure default configurations, and exposure of sensitive information. However, once the misconfiguration is in place, it can provide multiple attack vectors for threat agents. These threat agents can be external or internal to the organization. External threat agents such as hackers, ransomware operators, or cyber-criminal groups can exploit the misconfiguration to gain unauthorized access, steal sensitive data or launch attacks on the system. Internal threat agents can include disgruntled employees or insider threats who exploit the misconfiguration for malicious intent.

Impacts

The potential impacts are considerable and diverse. They could result in unauthorized data access which may comprise sensitive or personal data, leading to significant data breaches. This can consequently damage a company's reputation and violate data protection regulations, potentially leading to large fines. In addition, these threats can open the door for malware or ransomware attacks that can disrupt the normal functioning of serverless applications or even entire systems, impacting business operations. 

Example Attack Scenarios

Scenario 1: An organization accidentally leaves a serverless function with open permissions. A hacker discovers this misconfiguration, allowing them to invoke the function at will. They proceed to exfiltrate sensitive data from the connected database, leading to a large-scale data breach. 

Scenario 2: An internal developer erroneously configures a serverless function to write to a log file but forgets to secure the file appropriately. An insider threat stumbles upon this misconfiguration and uses it to leak proprietary company information. 

Scenario 3: Due to a oversight in the configuration process, a company leaves debugging information exposed in their serverless environment. Cyber criminals discover this and exploit it to uncover system vulnerabilities, which they then use to inject malware into the system, causing significant disruptions and damage to operations and infrastructure.

countermeasure.name: Apply Vault Access Policies to enforce granular permissions on Glacier vaults
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure secure access to AWS S3 Glacier vaults, apply Vault Access Policies that specify which users or roles can perform specific actions, such as read or write operations. This helps enforce the principle of least privilege and prevents unauthorized access.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Create an Access Policy: Define a JSON policy outlining permitted actions and authorized IAM users or roles.
  2. Attach the Policy: Use the AWS Console or CLI to apply the policy to the Glacier vault.
  3. Test and Monitor: Verify the policy works as intended and use AWS CloudTrail to monitor access.
  4. Review Regularly: Update policies as needed to align with changing security requirements.

countermeasure.name: Implement data retrieval policies to manage S3 Glacier retrieval costs
countermeasure.desc:
To effectively manage costs and optimize retrieval performance in AWS S3 Glacier, implement data retrieval policies. These policies control the amount of data that can be retrieved per hour and set retrieval priorities, such as Standard, Bulk, or Expedited, ensuring cost-effective data access.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Define a Retrieval Policy: Specify limits on data retrieval rates and set retrieval priorities based on business needs.
  2. Apply the Policy: Use the AWS Management Console or CLI to configure the retrieval policy on the S3 Glacier vault.
  3. Monitor Usage: Regularly review retrieval logs to ensure the policy is effective and adjust as needed to align with cost management goals.

countermeasure.name: Leverage S3 Glacier Select for in-place data querying
countermeasure.desc:
Use S3 Glacier Select to execute SQL queries directly on data stored in AWS S3 Glacier without fully retrieving it. This approach minimizes the costs and time associated with processing large, infrequently accessed datasets by retrieving only the necessary data for analysis.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Prepare SQL Queries: Write SQL queries that specify the data you need directly from the S3 Glacier storage.
  2. Use Glacier Select: Utilize the AWS Management Console, CLI, or SDKs to run these queries against the stored data in Glacier.
  3. Review Costs and Performance: Monitor the costs and performance benefits from using Glacier Select and adjust query parameters as needed to optimize cost savings.

countermeasure.name: Use S3 Glacier Deep Archive for long-term, infrequent access storage
countermeasure.desc:
For data that requires long-term retention but is rarely accessed, utilize AWS S3 Glacier Deep Archive. This storage class provides a cost-effective solution with retrieval times of up to 12 hours, making it ideal for compliance and archival data that does not need immediate access.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Select Glacier Deep Archive: Choose the Glacier Deep Archive storage class when creating or updating S3 bucket policies for long-term data storage.
  2. Configure Data Lifecycle Policies: Set up lifecycle policies to automatically transition infrequently accessed data to Glacier Deep Archive after a specified period.
  3. Plan for Retrieval Times: Be aware of the longer retrieval times (up to 12 hours) and plan access requirements accordingly.

countermeasure.name: Use S3 Glacier Vault Lock to enforce immutability for compliance
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure regulatory compliance and protect data integrity, configure S3 Glacier Vault Lock on your AWS S3 Glacier vaults. Vault Lock allows you to create a lockable policy that enforces a Write Once, Read Many (WORM) model. Once the Vault Lock policy is set and locked, it becomes immutable, meaning no user, including those with administrative privileges, can modify or delete data. This is crucial for meeting regulatory requirements that mandate the preservation of records in their original state.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Create a Vault Lock Policy: Navigate to the AWS Management Console, open the S3 Glacier service, and select the vault for which you want to apply the policy.
  2. Define the WORM Policy: Write a Vault Lock policy specifying the compliance rules, such as retention periods and actions that are restricted (e.g., delete or overwrite).
  3. Initiate the Vault Lock Process: Apply the policy to the vault and initiate the Vault Lock. The policy enters a 'pending' state during which you can test it by attempting operations that would be restricted by the policy.
  4. Lock the Policy: After testing, finalize the policy to lock it. Once locked, the policy becomes immutable, ensuring data cannot be altered or deleted.
  5. Monitor Compliance: Regularly audit the vault to ensure no unauthorized changes have been made and that the data complies with your regulatory and retention requirements.

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Inefficient data processing
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Inefficient Data Processing refers to the costly and time-consuming retrieval of large datasets from AWS S3 Glacier for analysis. Glacier is optimized for long-term archival storage, not frequent or real-time data processing, making full data retrieval operations potentially inefficient and expensive.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Threat Agents: Data analysts, automated workflows, or applications not optimized for Glacier's retrieval constraints.
  • Attack Vectors: Full data retrievals for analysis, lack of using tools like S3 Glacier Select for targeted queries, or improper configuration of data processing tasks.

Impacts:

  • Financial Impact: Increased retrieval costs and processing overhead.
  • Operational Impact: Delays in data processing, increased workload on systems and personnel.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. A data scientist retrieves a complete dataset from S3 Glacier for analysis instead of using selective queries, resulting in unnecessary costs and time delays.
  2. Automated ETL processes are set up to retrieve and process entire data sets regularly, without consideration of the infrequent access pattern, leading to inefficiencies and higher expenses.

threat.name: Excessive data retrieval costs
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Excessive Data Retrieval Costs occur when large volumes of data are retrieved from AWS S3 Glacier, leading to unexpected high charges. S3 Glacier is intended for infrequent access, and costs can escalate quickly with frequent or high-speed retrievals.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Threat Agents: Internal users, misconfigured systems, malicious insiders, or external attackers with access to AWS credentials.
  • Attack Vectors: Automated retrieval processes, bulk or expedited data requests, compromised credentials.

Impacts:

  • Financial Impact: High costs affecting budget and operations.
  • Operational Impact: Resource reallocation, project delays.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An employee unintentionally triggers a bulk data retrieval, causing unexpected charges.
  2. A compromised account is used to request large amounts of data, leading to financial loss and potential data breaches.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1210 - Exploitation of Remote Services

threat.name: High costs of long-term storage
threat.desc:
High Costs of Long-Term Storage occur when data stored in AWS S3 Glacier, particularly in higher-cost storage classes like Glacier Deep Archive, accumulates over time, leading to increased expenses. Without proper lifecycle management, data that remains stored without being accessed can result in unnecessarily high storage costs.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Threat Agents: Internal users, administrators, or systems lacking proper storage policies.
  • Attack Vectors: Retaining data in expensive storage classes without regular reviews or applying lifecycle policies to move infrequently accessed data to cheaper storage.

Impacts:

  • Financial Impact: Increased storage costs, affecting budget allocations and potentially leading to wasteful spending.
  • Operational Impact: Misallocation of resources that could otherwise be optimized for cost-efficiency.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An organization fails to implement lifecycle policies, leaving large amounts of old data in Glacier Deep Archive, resulting in substantial monthly charges.
  2. A data lake is set to store all data in S3 Glacier without differentiating between active and inactive datasets, leading to high costs for infrequently accessed data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to Glacier vaults
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Unauthorized Access to Glacier Vaults occurs when unauthorized users gain access to AWS S3 Glacier vaults, potentially leading to data breaches, data manipulation, or loss. Glacier vaults are intended to store highly sensitive or critical archival data, and inadequate access controls can result in unauthorized actions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers with stolen credentials, or misconfigured user permissions.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploiting weak access controls, using compromised AWS credentials, or leveraging overly permissive vault access policies to gain unauthorized access to Glacier vaults.

Impacts:

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized users may exfiltrate sensitive data.
  • Data Loss or Manipulation: Critical data may be deleted or altered, impacting business continuity and compliance.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker gains access to AWS credentials with permissions to a Glacier vault and deletes critical archival data, causing irreparable loss.
  2. A misconfigured vault access policy allows an unauthorized internal user to access and manipulate sensitive compliance data, leading to regulatory violations.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1219 - Remote Access Software

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Data integrity and compliance violations
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Data Integrity and Compliance Violations occur when data stored in AWS S3 Glacier is tampered with, deleted, or not stored in a manner compliant with regulatory requirements. Glacier is often used for long-term storage of critical data, such as financial records or legal documents, where maintaining data integrity and adhering to compliance standards are crucial.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers, or misconfigured systems.
  • Attack Vectors: Unauthorized modifications or deletions due to inadequate access controls, lack of immutable storage configurations (like WORM policies), or errors in data handling processes.

Impacts:

  • Compliance Impact: Breaches in regulatory requirements can result in fines, legal action, and loss of certifications.
  • Operational Impact: Corrupted or lost data can affect business continuity, damage reputation, and hinder decision-making processes.
  • Financial Impact: Costs associated with data recovery, legal fines, and potential loss of business.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An internal employee with excessive permissions accidentally deletes or alters archived financial records, resulting in non-compliance with financial reporting regulations.
  2. An external attacker gains unauthorized access to a Glacier vault and deletes sensitive legal documents stored for compliance purposes, causing the organization to fail audits and face regulatory penalties.
  3. A misconfigured automated script overwrites critical archival data in Glacier, resulting in permanent data loss and failure to meet data retention requirements.

weakness.name: CWE-1125
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1125: Excessive Attack Surface The product has an attack surface whose quantitative measurement exceeds a desirable maximum.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-250
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-250: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges The product performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.

weakness.name: CWE-276
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-276: Incorrect Default Permissions During installation, installed file permissions are set to allow anyone to modify those files.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-352
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-352: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) The web application does not, or can not, sufficiently verify whether a well-formed, valid, consistent request was intentionally provided by the user who submitted the request. When a web server is designed to receive a request from a client without any mechanism for verifying that it was intentionally sent, then it might be possible for an attacker to trick a client into making an unintentional request to the web server which will be treated as an authentic request. This can be done via a URL, image load, XMLHttpRequest, etc. and can result in exposure of data or unintended code execution.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

countermeasure.name: Consider encryption of data at rest
countermeasure.desc:
You have the following options for protecting data at rest in Amazon S3:

  • Server-side encryption All Amazon S3 buckets have encryption configured by default, and all new objects that are uploaded to an S3 bucket are automatically encrypted at rest. Server-side encryption with Amazon S3 managed keys (SSE-S3) is the default encryption configuration for every bucket in Amazon S3. To use a different type of encryption, you can either specify the type of server-side encryption to use in your S3 PUT requests, or you can set the default encryption configuration in the destination bucket.

Amazon S3 also provides these server-side encryption options:

  • Server-side encryption with AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) keys (SSE-KMS)
  • Dual-layer server-side encryption with AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) keys (DSSE-KMS)
  • Server-side encryption with customer-provided keys (SSE-C)

For more information, see Protecting data with server-side encryption.

  • Client-side encryption Encrypt data client-side and upload the encrypted data to Amazon S3. In this case, you manage the encryption process, the encryption keys, and related tools. As with server-side encryption, client-side encryption can help reduce risk by encrypting the data with a key that is stored in a different mechanism than the mechanism that stores the data itself.

Amazon S3 provides multiple client-side encryption options. For more information, see Protecting data by using client-side encryption.

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information
SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Consider using S3 Cross-Region Replication
countermeasure.desc:
Although Amazon S3 stores your data across multiple geographically diverse Availability Zones by default, compliance requirements might dictate that you store data at even greater distances. With S3 Cross-Region Replication (CRR), you can replicate data between distant AWS Regions to help satisfy these requirements. CRR enables automatic, asynchronous copying of objects across buckets in different AWS Regions. For more information, see Replicating objects.

Note

CRR requires both the source and destination S3 buckets to have versioning enabled.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-replication-enabled managed AWS Config rule.

countermeasure.desc:

For more information, see Using S3 Object Lock.

countermeasure.name: Disable access control lists (ACLs)and use bucket policies to manage permissions
countermeasure.desc:
S3 Object Ownership is an Amazon S3 bucket-level setting that you can use to control ownership of objects uploaded to your bucket and to disable or enable ACLs. By default, Object Ownership is set to the Bucket owner enforced setting and all ACLs are disabled. When ACLs are disabled, the bucket owner owns all the objects in the bucket and manages access to data exclusively using access management policies.

A majority of modern use cases in Amazon S3 no longer require the use of access control lists (ACLs). We recommend that you disable ACLs, except in unusual circumstances where you must control access for each object individually. To disable ACLs and take ownership of every object in your bucket, apply the bucket owner enforced setting for S3 Object Ownership. When you disable ACLs, you can easily maintain a bucket with objects uploaded by different AWS accounts.

When ACLs are disabled access control for your data is based on policies, such as the following:

  • AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) user policies
  • S3 bucket policies
  • Virtual private cloud (VPC) endpoint policies
  • AWS Organizations service control policies (SCPs)

Disabling ACLs simplifies permissions management and auditing. ACLs are disabled for new buckets by default. You can also disable ACLs for existing buckets. If you have an existing bucket that already has objects in it, after you disable ACLs, the object and bucket ACLs are no longer part of the access-evaluation process. Instead, access is granted or denied on the basis of policies.

Before you disable ACLs, make sure that you do the following:

  • Review your bucket policy to ensure that it covers all the ways that you intend to grant access to your bucket outside of your account.
  • Reset your bucket ACL to the default (full control to the bucket owner).

After you disable ACLs, the following behaviors occur:

  • Your bucket accepts only PUT requests that do not specify an ACL or PUT requests with bucket owner full control ACLs. These ACLs include the bucket-owner-full-control canned ACL or equivalent forms of this ACL that are expressed in XML.
  • Existing applications that support bucket owner full control ACLs see no impact.
  • PUT requests that contain other ACLs (for example, custom grants to certain AWS accounts) fail and return an HTTP status code 400 (Bad Request) with the error code AccessControlListNotSupported.

For more information, see Controlling ownership of objects and disabling ACLs for your bucket.

countermeasure.name: Discover sensitive data by using Amazon Macie
countermeasure.desc:
Amazon Macie is a security service that discovers sensitive data by using machine learning and pattern matching. Macie provides visibility into data security risks, and enables automated protection against those risks. With Macie, you can automate the discovery and reporting of sensitive data in your Amazon S3 data estate to gain a better understanding of the data that your organization stores in S3.

To detect sensitive data with Macie, you can use built-in criteria and techniques that are designed to detect a large and growing list of sensitive data types for many countries and regions. These sensitive data types include multiple types of personally identifiable information (PII), financial data, and credentials data. You can also use custom criteria that you defineregular expressions that define text patterns to match and, optionally, character sequences and proximity rules that refine the results.

If Macie detects sensitive data in an S3 object, Macie generates a security finding to notify you. This finding provides information about the affected object, the types and number of occurrences of the sensitive data that Macie found, and additional details to help you investigate the affected S3 bucket and object. For more information, see the Amazon Macie User Guide.

countermeasure.name: Enable AWS Config
countermeasure.desc:
Several of the best practices listed in this topic suggest creating AWS Config rules. AWS Config helps you to assess, audit, and evaluate the configurations of your AWS resources. AWS Config monitors resource configurations so that you can evaluate the recorded configurations against the desired secure configurations. With AWS Config, you can do the following:

  • Review changes in configurations and relationships between AWS resources
  • Investigate detailed resource-configuration histories
  • Determine your overall compliance against the configurations specified in your internal guidelines

Using AWS Config can help you simplify compliance auditing, security analysis, change management, and operational troubleshooting. For more information, see Setting Up AWS Config with the Console in the AWS Config Developer Guide. When specifying the resource types to record, ensure that you include Amazon S3 resources.

Important

AWS Config managed rules only supports general purpose buckets when evaluating Amazon S3 resources. AWS Config doesnt record configuration changes for directory buckets. For more information, see AWS Config Managed Rules and List of AWS Config Managed Rules in the AWS Config Developer Guide.

For an example of how to use AWS Config, see How to Use AWS Config to Monitor for and Respond to Amazon S3 Buckets Allowing Public Access on the AWS Security Blog.

countermeasure.name: Enable S3 versioning
countermeasure.desc:
S3 Versioning is a means of keeping multiple variants of an object in the same bucket. You can use versioning to preserve, retrieve, and restore every version of every object stored in your bucket. With versioning, you can easily recover from both unintended user actions and application failures.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-versioning-enabled managed AWS Config rule.

For more information, see Using versioning in S3 buckets.

countermeasure.name: Enforce encryption of data in transit
countermeasure.desc:
You can use HTTPS (TLS) to help prevent potential attackers from eavesdropping on or manipulating network traffic by using person-in-the-middle or similar attacks. We recommend allowing only encrypted connections over HTTPS (TLS) by using the aws:SecureTransport condition in your Amazon S3 bucket policies.

Important

We recommend that your application not pin Amazon S3 TLS certificates as AWS doesnt support pinning of publicly-trusted certificates. S3 automatically renews certificates and renewal can happen any time before certificate expiry. Renewing a certificate generates a new public-private key pair. If youve pinned an S3 certificate which has been recently renewed with a new public key, you wont be able to connect to S3 until your application uses the new certificate.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-ssl-requests-only managed AWS Config rule.

countermeasure.name: Ensure that your Amazon S3 buckets use the correct policies and are not publicly accessible
countermeasure.desc:
Unless you explicitly require anyone on the internet to be able to read or write to your S3 bucket, make sure that your S3 bucket is not public. The following are some of the steps that you can take to block public access:

  • Use S3 Block Public Access. With S3 Block Public Access, you can easily set up centralized controls to limit public access to your Amazon S3 resources. These centralized controls are enforced regardless of how the resources are created. For more information, see Blocking public access to your Amazon S3 storage.
  • Identify Amazon S3 bucket policies that allow a wildcard identity such as "Principal": "*" (which effectively means "anyone"). Also look for policies that allow a wildcard action "*" (which effectively allows the user to perform any action in the Amazon S3 bucket).
  • Similarly, look for Amazon S3 bucket access control lists (ACLs) that provide read, write, or full-access to "Everyone" or "Any authenticated AWS user."
  • Use the ListBuckets API operation to scan all of your Amazon S3 buckets. Then use GetBucketAcl, GetBucketWebsite, and GetBucketPolicy to determine whether each bucket has compliant access controls and a compliant configuration.
  • Use AWS Trusted Advisor to inspect your Amazon S3 implementation.
  • Consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-public-read-prohibited and s3-bucket-public-write-prohibited managed AWS Config Rules.

For more information, see Identity and Access Management for Amazon S3.

countermeasure.name: Identify and audit all of your Amazon S3 buckets
countermeasure.desc:
Identification of your IT assets is a crucial aspect of governance and security. You need to have visibility of all your Amazon S3 resources to assess their security posture and take action on potential areas of weakness. To audit your resources, we recommend doing the following:

  • Use Tag Editor to identify and tag security-sensitive or audit-sensitive resources, then use those tags when you need to search for these resources. For more information, see Searching for Resources to Tag in the Tagging AWS Resources User Guide.
  • Use S3 Inventory to audit and report on the replication and encryption status of your objects for business, compliance, and regulatory needs. For more information, see Amazon S3 Inventory.
  • Create resource groups for your Amazon S3 resources. For more information, see What are resource groups? in the AWS Resource Groups User Guide.

countermeasure.name: Identify potential threats to your Amazon S3 buckets by using Amazon GuardDuty
countermeasure.desc: Amazon GuardDuty is a threat detection service that identifies potential threats to your accounts, containers, workloads, and the data within your AWS environment. By using machine learning (ML) models, and anomaly and threat detection capabilities, Amazon GuardDuty continuously monitors different data sources to identify and prioritize potential security risks and malicious activities in your environment. When you enable GuardDuty, it offers threat detection for foundational data sources that includes AWS CloudTrail management events, VPC flow logs, and DNS logs. To extend threat detection to data plane events in S3 buckets, you can enable the GuardDuty S3 Protection feature. This feature detects threats such as data exfiltration and suspicious access to S3 buckets via Tor nodes. GuardDuty also establishes a normal baseline pattern in your environment and when it identifies a potentially anomalous behavior, it provides contextual information to help you remediate the potentially compromised S3 bucket or AWS credentials. For more information, see GuardDuty.

countermeasure.name: Implement least privilege access
countermeasure.desc:
When granting permissions, you decide who is getting what permissions to which Amazon S3 resources. You enable specific actions that you want to allow on those resources. Therefore, we recommend that you grant only the permissions that are required to perform a task. Implementing least privilege access is fundamental in reducing security risk and the impact that could result from errors or malicious intent.

The following tools are available to implement least privilege access:

  • Policy actions for Amazon S3 and Permissions Boundaries for IAM Entities
  • How Amazon S3 works with IAM
  • Access control list (ACL) overview
  • Service Control Policies

For guidance on what to consider when choosing one or more of the preceding mechanisms, see Identity and Access Management for Amazon S3.

countermeasure.name: Implement monitoring by using AWS monitoring tools
countermeasure.desc:
Monitoring is an important part of maintaining the reliability, security, availability, and performance of Amazon S3 and your AWS solutions. AWS provides several tools and services to help you monitor Amazon S3 and your other AWS services. For example, you can monitor Amazon CloudWatch metrics for Amazon S3, particularly the PutRequests, GetRequests, 4xxErrors, and DeleteRequests metrics. For more information, see Monitoring metrics with Amazon CloudWatch and Monitoring Amazon S3.

For a second example, see Example: Amazon S3 Bucket Activity. This example describes how to create a CloudWatch alarm that is triggered when an Amazon S3 API call is made to PUT or DELETE a bucket policy, a bucket lifecycle, or a bucket replication configuration, or to PUT a bucket ACL.

countermeasure.name: Use AWS CloudTrail
countermeasure.desc:
AWS CloudTrail provides a record of actions taken by a user, a role, or an AWS service in Amazon S3. You can use information collected by CloudTrail to determine the following:

  • The request that was made to Amazon S3
  • The IP address from which the request was made
  • Who made the request
  • When the request was made
  • Additional details about the request

For example, you can identify CloudTrail entries for PUT actions that affect data access, in particular PutBucketAcl, PutObjectAcl, PutBucketPolicy, and PutBucketWebsite.

When you set up your AWS account, CloudTrail is enabled by default. You can view recent events in the CloudTrail console. To create an ongoing record of activity and events for your Amazon S3 buckets, you can create a trail in the CloudTrail console. For more information, see Logging data events in the AWS CloudTrail User Guide.

When you create a trail, you can configure CloudTrail to log data events. Data events are records of resource operations performed on or within a resource. In Amazon S3, data events record object-level API activity for individual buckets. CloudTrail supports a subset of Amazon S3 object-level API operations, such as GetObject, DeleteObject, and PutObject. For more information about how CloudTrail works with Amazon S3, see Logging Amazon S3 API calls using AWS CloudTrail. In the Amazon S3 console, you can also configure your S3 buckets to Enabling CloudTrail event logging for S3 buckets and objects.

AWS Config provides a managed rule (cloudtrail-s3-dataevents-enabled) that you can use to confirm that at least one CloudTrail trail is logging data events for your S3 buckets. For more information, see cloudtrail-s3-dataevents-enabled in the AWS Config Developer Guide.

countermeasure.name: Use IAM roles for applications and AWS services that require Amazon S3 access
countermeasure.desc:
In order for applications running on Amazon EC2 or other AWS services to access Amazon S3 resources, they must include valid AWS credentials in their AWS API requests. We recommend not storing AWS credentials directly in the application or Amazon EC2 instance. These are long-term credentials that are not automatically rotated and could have a significant business impact if they are compromised.

Instead, use an IAM role to manage temporary credentials for applications or services that need to access Amazon S3. When you use a role, you don't have to distribute long-term credentials (such as a username and password or access keys) to an Amazon EC2 instance or AWS service, such as AWS Lambda. The role supplies temporary permissions that applications can use when they make calls to other AWS resources.

For more information, see the following topics in the IAM User Guide:

  • IAM Roles
  • Common Scenarios for Roles: Users, Applications, and Services

countermeasure.name: Use S3 Storage Lens
countermeasure.desc:
S3 Storage Lens is a cloud-storage analytics feature that you can use to gain organization-wide visibility into object-storage usage and activity. S3 Storage Lens also analyzes metrics to deliver contextual recommendations that you can use to optimize storage costs and apply best practices for protecting your data.

With S3 Storage Lens, you can use metrics to generate summary insights, such as finding out how much storage you have across your entire organization or which are the fastest-growing buckets and prefixes. You can also use S3 Storage Lens metrics to identify cost-optimization opportunities, implement data-protection and access-management best practices, and improve the performance of application workloads.

For example, you can identify buckets that don't have S3 Lifecycle rules to abort incomplete multipart uploads that are more than 7 days old. You can also identify buckets that aren't following data-protection best practices, such as using S3 Replication or S3 Versioning. For more information, see Understanding Amazon S3 Storage Lens.

standard.ref: PR.PT-1: Audit/log records are determined, documented, implemented, and reviewed in accordance with policy

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized extraction of sensitive data from S3 buckets
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Sensitive data stored in Amazon S3 buckets may be extracted without proper oversight due to inadequate monitoring and insufficient access controls. This can lead to unauthorized data access, leaks, and breaches, compromising the integrity and confidentiality of the data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include malicious insiders, external attackers, and compromised accounts. Attack vectors involve exploiting weak access controls, lack of encryption, and insufficient logging and monitoring mechanisms, allowing undetected data exfiltration.

Impacts

Impacts include severe data breaches, loss of intellectual property, financial losses, legal consequences due to non-compliance with data protection regulations, and damage to an organization's reputation and customer trust.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An insider with access to an S3 bucket containing sensitive customer information downloads the data without being detected due to a lack of proper monitoring and oversight.
  2. An external attacker compromises an employee's AWS credentials and uses them to extract sensitive data from an S3 bucket, leading to a significant data breach and regulatory fines.
  3. Sensitive financial data stored in an S3 bucket is exfiltrated by an attacker exploiting overly permissive access controls, resulting in the exposure of confidential business information and competitive disadvantage.
  4. A lack of proper logging and alerting mechanisms allows an attacker to continuously extract small amounts of sensitive data over an extended period, going unnoticed until the breach is discovered during an audit.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1011 - Exfiltration Over Other Network Medium

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Inadequate monitoring of S3 buckets
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

The lack of adequate monitoring of Amazon S3 buckets can result in undetected data breaches or data loss. Without proper logging, alerting, and monitoring mechanisms, unauthorized access or malicious activities can go unnoticed, leading to severe security and compliance issues.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers, malicious insiders, and compromised accounts. Attack vectors involve exploiting weak or non-existent monitoring systems, allowing attackers to access, modify, or extract data without detection.

Impacts

Impacts include significant data breaches, loss of sensitive and critical data, non-compliance with regulatory requirements, financial losses, and damage to the organization's reputation and customer trust. The inability to detect and respond to security incidents in a timely manner exacerbates these risks.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker gains unauthorized access to an S3 bucket and exfiltrates sensitive data over time. Due to inadequate monitoring, the breach remains undetected until the data is leaked or sold on the dark web, resulting in a major security incident.
  2. An insider with malicious intent deletes critical business data from an S3 bucket. Without proper monitoring and alerting mechanisms, the data loss is not identified until business operations are disrupted, causing significant financial and operational impacts.
  3. During a routine compliance audit, an organization discovers that an S3 bucket containing regulated data has been accessed by unauthorized users multiple times over the past year, leading to substantial fines and legal consequences.
  4. A lack of detailed logging and alerting allows an attacker to use compromised credentials to make unauthorized changes to an S3 bucket policy, granting themselves ongoing access and leading to a prolonged data breach that goes unnoticed for months.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Insecure S3 bucket configurations
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Amazon S3 buckets that are not properly secured may be accessible by unauthorized users. This can result from misconfigured permissions, lack of encryption, and absence of stringent access controls, leading to potential data breaches and unauthorized data access.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers, malicious insiders, and automated bots scanning for misconfigured buckets. Attack vectors involve exploiting weak or incorrect bucket policies, overly permissive access controls, and publicly accessible buckets without proper security measures.

Impacts

Impacts include unauthorized access to sensitive data, data breaches, loss of intellectual property, compliance violations, financial penalties, and damage to the organization's reputation. Misconfigured buckets can also lead to data manipulation or deletion, further compromising data integrity and availability.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An S3 bucket containing confidential customer data is mistakenly configured with public read access, allowing anyone on the internet to access and download sensitive information, resulting in a significant data breach.
  2. During a routine security scan, it is discovered that several S3 buckets are accessible to unauthorized internal users due to misconfigured IAM policies, leading to unauthorized access and potential data leaks.
  3. An external attacker uses automated tools to identify and access an S3 bucket that has been inadvertently left publicly accessible. The attacker exfiltrates proprietary business information, causing financial and reputational damage to the company.
  4. A developer unintentionally grants write permissions to all authenticated AWS users on an S3 bucket, allowing unauthorized users to upload malicious content or delete critical data, leading to operational disruptions and potential legal issues.
